Beach House Waterfront Restaurant | Bradenton Beach Venue | PartySlate Skip to content Venues Planners Vendors Ideas Venues Planners Vendors Ideas Beach House Waterfront Restaurant Find Venues / Florida / Bradenton Beach / Beach House Waterfront Restaurant Beach House Waterfront Restaurant 200 Gulf Dr N, Bradenton Beach, FL 34217, USA Max Seated 80 Max Standing 100 Request info Favorite Average Response Time 1-2 days Overview Gallery 5 About Beach House Waterfront Restaurant Set on a pristine Gulf front beach, the Beach House Restaurant features a climate-friendly outdoor deck providing beautiful oceanfront vistas and signature Anna Maria Island sunsets on display every evening. The Beach House is a model for environmentally friendly development and operations.

The Sunset Deck at the Beach House Waterfront Restaurant offers flexible indoor, outdoor open-aired event spaces, and can comfortably accommodate up to 85 guests. The Sunset Deck features 840 square feet of space overlooking the gorgeous Gulf of Mexico. As one of the only beachfront venues in the area, there are plenty of photo pop-ready vignettes waiting for you. Spacious dressing rooms with luxe decor and camera-ready lighting set the stage for a picture-perfect day. Walk down an aisle of pristine white sand with the Gulf’s blue-green water and cloudless skies as your beautiful backdrop. Let the slight sea breeze kiss your face as you say,” I do.”

At the reception, your guests can dine under the covered patio with the ability to control the interior climate on hot and humid days. This completely private setting is reserved just for you so that you can enjoy lifelong memories in privacy and comfort. The space is also perfect for engagement parties, bridal showers, rehearsal dinners, and farewell brunches, providing you with a perfect location to celebrate every moment of your marriage. Event Spaces 1 80 max seated • 100 max standing 7 The Sunset Deck 100 Seated 100 Standing Restaurant Bar Outdoor Event Space Meeting Space Waterfront Beach Pricing Packages Beach House Waterfront Restaurant Pricing Est. Name * First Name Last Name Email * Reason for Contact * General Inquiry Special Events Employment Lost & Found Gift Shop Bakery Gift Cards How can we help today? * Thank you! Frequently Asked Questions What is your pet policy? Service Animals Only We love furry friends, however, when you come and eat at the Sandbar or Beach House, pets should stay home! If you visit Mar Vista by boat, please keep them on your boat while you pick up your food. We follow the Manatee County pet policy. Animals are not allowed in the restaurant unless providing a service to their owner. Please come join us soon for an unforgettable experience, but Buddy and FiFi are going to have to sit this one out. This is for all of our guest’s health and safety as well as your pets! What are you accesibilty options? Beach House can accommodate wheelchairs indoors or outdoors. Do you take reservations? We do not take reservations at the Beach House Waerfront Retaurant. Where can I park? Beach House Waterfront Restaurant | Sip, Eat, and Fun in a Waterfront Sunset 0 Skip to Content About Our Restaurant Events Shop Merchandise Gift Cards Contact Job Openings Careers Menu Open Menu Close Menu Menu About Our Restaurant Events Shop Merchandise Gift Cards Contact Job Openings Careers Open Menu Close Menu Folder: About Back Our Restaurant Events Folder: Shop Back Merchandise Gift Cards Contact Job Openings Careers Menu SIPS EATS & FUN Fresh Beachfront Dining since 1993 SCROLL DOWN Sun, fun, and feast at Beach House Cocktails and fresh seafood taste that much better when dining with a 650ft view of the Gulf of Mexico. Our covered deck and outdoor bar are open year-round and are the perfect setting for larger groups and intimate occasions. We love welcoming guests back time and again. Explore the Menu Eat . Drink . Relax . Repeat . We’re proud of our sustainable & locally-sourced menu creation. LUNCH HAPPY HOUR SUNSET DINNER Explore the Menu What People Are Saying “Refreshing and beautiful decor. Gorgeous beach views. Pleasant and skilled servers .. especially Beth! Our food was fresh and delicious!” Natalie R. | Google “Excellent food, excellent service, excellent view! Truly one of the best meals we have had in a very long time, all of our dishes were perfectly cooked. Very tasty and amazing presentation.” Vaz20 | TripAdvisor “Phenomenal food! The service is A1 very kind and cooperative! The atmosphere is perfect with an amazing ocean view! A must-eat if you are in Anna Maria or near Bradenton Beach!” Keifer N. | Yelp See what others are saying Book now Special Events A location with unbeatable views Your event will look like a beautiful film location with unbeatable views, a state-of-the-art and climate-controlled dining area, and a personal dressing suite. With an exquisite menu filled with locally sourced seafood, produce, and more, we’ve got your event covered, rain or shine. Gifts & Goods Merchandise Take home the memories! Visit the gift shop in our lobby for the latest Florida styles, branded merch, and all your beachside essentials. Select items available online and shipped to your home. Shop Online Gift Cards Give the gift of taste!  Order a gift card to use at any of our restaurants - Sandbar, Beach House, and Mar Vista. About Us - Maggie Mae's Waterfront Skip to content 727-595-1096 info@maggiemaeswaterfront.com Mon - Sun: 7:00am - 2:00pm Maggie Maes Waterfront Facebook-f Home Our Menu Location About Gift Cards Home Our Menu Location About Gift Cards Order Now About Us Our Story It was never our intent to create an iconic breakfast and lunch spot near Clearwater Beach. We just wanted a place to get a great breakfast and lunch on the waterfront. After sixteen years and thousands of positive reviews by guests all over the world, we feel comfortable our goal was met and then some. Since 2004 Maggie Mae’s Waterfront has hosted locals and visitors from almost every country in the world. In the mix were some celebrities like Detroit quarterback Matt Stafford, wrestling legend Hulk Hogan, Phillies star Bryce Harper, NBA star Matt Geiger, NFL coach John Gruden and many more. The real stars remain the families who travel to the area for a little rest and relaxation. Their children enjoy the activities on the waterfront with the dolphins and occasional manatee. Join us for a relaxing breakfast or lunch on the waterfront – be one of our celebrities! Video Tour Maggie Mae’s Waterfront 1261 Gulf Blvd 727-595-1096 Mon – Sun: 7:00am – 2:00pm Navigation Home Our Menu Contact About Quick Links eClub Signup Traditional Gift Cards Florida Travel Sites Facebook © 2024 All rights reserved Maggie Mae's Waterfront HALF OFF Any Entree On Your Birthday! * indicates required Email Address * First Name Last Name Phone Number ( ) - (###) ###-#### Birthday * / ( mm / dd ) Join Our Eclub New Eclub Rewards Effective 9-1-2022 You will get our bi-monthly newsletters with food news and Florida happenings. Parties, new menu items and events will be announced by email. Seasonal coupons & discounts. BIRTHDAY Reward - HALF OFF any entrée on our menu. Plus - a FREE Maggie Mae’s cookie!​

Let’s start with a stunning waterfront view, white sandy beach, and one of the largest gulf-front decks on the west coast of Florida. Weddings Beach House has the perfect combination of award-winning culinary choices, and a multitude of beach, deck and decor options. Our expert staff will help plan, coordinate and assist with every aspect of your big day at the perfect location…the Sunset Deck at the Beach House. Spectacular sunsets included! Ready to learn more about planning your wedding or social event at the Beach House? Gatherings Do you want to thank your staff for their loyalty, host a product release party, or corporate training day? Perhaps you want to host a birthday party, anniversary, or celebration of life by the water. We can help you plan out your entire event. Tell us a little about your needs and our team will help you plan the perfect gathering! Bradenton Beach waterfront restaurant reopens 6 weeks after hurricanes: 'Many hands make light work' | FOX 13 Tampa Bay News Weather Sports Good Day We Live Here Contests More Watch Live Expand / Collapse search ☰ Search site News Top Stories Local Tampa Bay News Florida Tonight National FOX 13 Investigates Consumer Health Politics Seen on TV Daily Newsletter FOX News Sunday Rhythm Roots Weather SkyTower Radar Views Interactive Radar Live Webcams Marine Weather Weather Alerts Hurricane Safety Tracking the Tropics MyFoxHurricane FOX Weather Sports Buccaneers Rays Lightning No Off Days with Scott Smith Weekly Fishing Report High School Sports Good Day Traffic Charley's World Hometown Heroes Extraordinary Ordinaries Recipes First Birthdays We Live Here What's Right Dinner DeeAs One Tank Trips Theme Parks Made in Tampa Bay Recipes, Food & Drink Tampa Bay History Care Force Watch Live How To Stream Live FOX 13 Newscasts LiveNOW from FOX FOX Weather FOX Soul FOX Live Feed Central NASA TV Money Consumer Personal Finance The Economy Small Business Entertainment Headlines Trending Stories FOX Shows What's on FOX 13 Contests Tampa Bay Reads Regional News Orlando News - FOX 35 Orlando Gainesville News - FOX 51 Gainesville Atlanta News - FOX 5 Atlanta About Us Meet the FOX 13 team TV Listings Jobs & Internships WTVT History Closed Captioning FCC Public File FCC Applications Contact Us Bradenton Beach waterfront restaurant reopens 6 weeks after hurricanes: 'Many hands make light work' By Kimberly Kuizon Published November 11, 2024 5:01pm EST Bradenton FOX 13 News Share Copy Link Email Facebook Twitter LinkedIn Reddit Beach House restaurant reopens after storms FOX 13's Kim Kuizon reports on Beach House restaurant in Bradenton Beach reopening six weeks after Hurricanes Helene and Milton forced them to close. BRADENTON BEACH, Fla. - One of Bradenton Beach’s many beachfront restaurants saw friends toast the day it finally reopened six weeks after Hurricanes Milton and Helene . Beach House Water has reopened its doors after dealing with flooding and land damage caused by the storms. Outside of Bradenton Beaches Beach House restaurant. "We are very relieved, very happy, and we are here to help support these businesses down here," said Manatee County resident Victor Becks. It’s a beacon of hope as Bradenton Beach continues to build back from hurricanes Helene and Milton. READ MORE: Bay Area teen overcomes obstacles, becomes Shriners ambassador Helene’s storm surge brought nearly four feet of sand across the property and a few inches of water inside. "In such a short period of time, they’ve made some serious miracles happen," said Becks. Jon O’Driscoll, the restaurant’s General Manager, said teams of Beach House employees showed up every day to clean and shovel sand left from the storms. "It’s the old; many hands make light work. It’s incredible how many things you can get done with just whatever people you can put together," said O’Driscoll. "We’d bring in teams of ten, and they would do so much work I’d come in surprised the next day." According to O’Driscoll, the teams were so efficient that he asked, "How did we move that much sand and clear that driveway?" One of the teams cleaning hurricane damage from Beach House restaurant. READ MORE: Sarasota restaurant offering authentic flavors of Amish cooking That work helped Daniel Sullivan, the Director of Southwest Operations for Beachside Hospitality Group, make sure employees didn’t miss out on a paycheck. "We just took over these restaurants a few short months ago, so we looked at this as an optimistic opportunity to really get boots on the ground and really be elbow to elbow with our staff and meet people in a much closer basis," said Sullivan. According to Sullivan, the water looks just as picturesque as ever, and Beach House is ready for much better times ahead. "We are ready with open arms to welcome everybody back to the beaches," said Sullivan. A view inside of the Beach House restaurant. READ MORE: USF breaks ground on new on-campus stadium Beachside Hospitality Group also owns the Sandbar on Anna Maria Island . They’ve been able to host weddings and said they will be reopening the Sandbar, later his week. The Mar Vista on Longboat Key will hopefully be able to reopen sometime next week. Job Openings | Beach House Waterfront Restaurant 0 Skip to Content About Our Restaurant Events Shop Merchandise Gift Cards Contact Job Openings Careers Menu Open Menu Close Menu Menu About Our Restaurant Events Shop Merchandise Gift Cards Contact Job Openings Careers Open Menu Close Menu Folder: About Back Our Restaurant Events Folder: Shop Back Merchandise Gift Cards Contact Job Openings Careers Menu JOB OPENINGS Apply now. Currently Hiring for: Restaurant Host/Retail Sales Associate Beachside Hospitality is looking for talented and dual-role sales staff/host to greet, seat, and check-out customers. Responsible for ensuring that customers have an exceptional experience by providing outstanding in-person and telephone service. Provide friendly, professional, and courteous service. Ensures that all work is performed in a timely, efficient, and safe manner according to company policies and procedures. Essential Duties & Responsibilities : ·       Exhibits a professional and friendly demeanor through appearance and by maintaining a positive attitude toward all employees, management, and customers. Capable of working as a part of a cohesive team and maintaining a positive, proactive attitude. Greet all guests with a friendly smile, demonstrating genuine hospitality Deliver exceptional service by providing knowledge of merchandise and menus Maintain a clean and sanitary environment for all team members and guests ·       Consistently comes to work neatly groomed, in full uniform with a visible nametag. Maintains an approachable demeanor throughout shift. ·       Provides a warm and friendly service experience to all those that call or enter the Gift Shop(s) by anticipating the needs of the guests. ·       Uses sales skills to promote items and assist each customer with their individual needs. ·       Accurately rings in all merchandise and provides an itemized receipt to each customer. ·       Helps conduct inventory of all merchandise as requested by management. ·       Alerts manager of any potential theft by fellow teammates, managers and/or customers. ·       Develops strong working relationships with all staff members to ensure communication and teamwork is at an optimum. ·       Identify ways of improving the efficiency and accuracy within the restaurant/gift shop. ·       Attempts to up-sell items to either enhance an existing purchase or recommend something the customer might not have seen while shopping. ·       Helps management maintain stock levels for retail items and general supplies, as requested, to ensure resources are readily available, properly stored and secured. ·       Continually restocks the retail floor in a neat manner, helping to ensure a variety of sizes and options are readily available. Required Skills/Qualifications : To perform this job successfully, an individual must be able to perform each essential duty satisfactorily. The requirements listed below are representative of the knowledge, skill, and/or ability required. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. Education : ·          High School Diploma or GED preferred. Experience : Minimum of 1 year experience in a store or restaurant. Excellent verbal communication and organizational skills with the ability to multitask, prioritize work and follow up on details. Qualifications : Flexible schedule to include weekends, holidays and varying shifts based on business demand. Able and willing to work overtime as business dictates. Experienced with various point-of-sale systems. Toast preferred. Name * First Name Last Name Email * Phone (###) ### #### Message * Please state what position you are looking for and upload your resume below. Thank you! Events | Beach House Waterfront Restaurant 0 Skip to Content About Our Restaurant Events Shop Merchandise Gift Cards Contact Job Openings Careers Menu Open Menu Close Menu Menu About Our Restaurant Events Shop Merchandise Gift Cards Contact Job Openings Careers Open Menu Close Menu Folder: About Back Our Restaurant Events Folder: Shop Back Merchandise Gift Cards Contact Job Openings Careers Menu Events Beachfront Gatherings Keep things perfect & stress-free. Let’s start with a stunning waterfront view, white sandy beach, and one of the largest gulf-front decks on the west coast of Florida. Weddings Beach House has the perfect combination of award-winning culinary choices, and a multitude of beach, deck and decor options. Our expert staff will help plan, coordinate and assist with every aspect of your big day at the perfect location…the Sunset Deck at the Beach House. Spectacular sunsets included! Ready to learn more about planning your wedding or social event at the Beach House? Gatherings Do you want to thank your staff for their loyalty, host a product release party, or corporate training day? Perhaps you want to host a birthday party, anniversary, or celebration of life by the water. We can help you plan out your entire event. Tell us a little about your needs and our team will help you plan the perfect gathering! Our Restaurant | Beach House Waterfront Restaurant 0 Skip to Content About Our Restaurant Events Shop Merchandise Gift Cards Contact Job Openings Careers Menu Open Menu Close Menu Menu About Our Restaurant Events Shop Merchandise Gift Cards Contact Job Openings Careers Open Menu Close Menu Folder: About Back Our Restaurant Events Folder: Shop Back Merchandise Gift Cards Contact Job Openings Careers Menu ABOUT Seafood with a View Set on pristine Gulf-front beach, the old Harbor House restaurant became Beach House in 1993. Purchased in 1993 as a vision of a moderately priced restaurant serving great seafood both indoors and outdoors transformed into what is the Beach House Waterfront Restaurant. Today the location features a climate friendly outdoor deck providing beautiful oceanfront vistas and signature Anna Maria Island sunsets on display every evening. Support the Local Environment Throughout the process of the renovations which were completed in the Spring of 2017, the mantra of “be a good steward of the environment” echoed from the construction to the menu and beyond. The Beach House is a model for environmentally friendly development and operations. New owners, big plans for the Beach House Skip to main content Skip to main content You are the owner of this article. Edit Article Add New Article Close You have permission to edit this article. Edit Close 69° Log In Subscribe Guest Logout Read Today's E-edition News Local Crime State & Regional Politics Business Education Nation & World Markets & Stocks News Tip Obituaries Share a story Recent Obituaries Find an Obituary Archives Opinion Submit a letter Letters Editorial Columnists Cartoons Sports High School College Professional Lifestyles Event Calendar Announcements Submit an Announcement Arts & Theatre Local Food & Cooking Movies & TV Music Contests & Promotions Comics Games & Puzzles Play Home & Garden Health Parenting Fashion People Pets Travel Faith Join the community News tip Share video Share a story Share a photo Brand Ave. Studios Print Edition E-edition E-edition Archives Special Sections Buy & Sell Place an Ad Jobs Cars Marketplace Shop Local I Love A Deal Public Notice Shopping Customer Service Manage Subscription Activate Digital Subscription Newsletter sign-up Subscribe Contact us Helpcenter Gift Subscription Mobile Apps Weather: Live Radar Facebook Twitter LinkedIn Instagram © 2025 Lee Enterprises Terms of Service | Privacy Policy Subscribe Read Today's E-edition Subscribe Log In Welcome, Guest My Subscription Help Center My Account Dashboard Profile Saved items Logout E-edition News Obituaries Opinion Sports Puzzles Lifestyles Public Notices Jobs 69° Clear Share This Facebook Twitter Bluesky WhatsApp SMS Email New owners, big plans for the Beach House 0 Comments Share this Facebook Twitter Bluesky WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save Alert Featured DECATUR New owners, big plans for the Beach House Scott Perry Feb 21, 2025 Feb 21, 2025 0 Facebook Twitter Bluesky WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save Todd Parker and Craig "Woody" Wilson pose for a portrait in front of the Beach House restaurant during renovations in Decatur on Tuesday, Feb. 11. JOSEPH RESSLER, HERALD & REVIEW DECATUR — The Beach House promised an experience that “will be bigger and better than ever before” when it announced its temporarily closure at the beginning of the new year for “major renovations.” In addition to its totally reconstructed dining area and a revamped menu, the list of “major” changes also includes new owners. Todd Parker and Craig “Woody” Wilson are now at the helm of this restaurant along Lake Decatur that is expected to open before March 11. They follow longtime owners Todd and Angie Mason. “The Beach House has been a passion project,” Parker said. “I don’t want to own restaurants, but I do want to own the Beach House.” Parker said his first memories of the building go back to his childhood, when he would walk along the lake shore with his mom, feeding the ducks. People are also reading… Oakley man dies in motorcycle crash Congratulations to H&R Player of the Week, Monticello's Mady Melton Week 2 high school football scores for Central Illinois Battle over mystery DNA intensifies in infamous Slover murder case Coroner releases name of Decatur shooting victim Decatur police car involved in hit-and-run Decatur teacher charged in sex-trafficking sting has died New ADM explosion lawsuit blames company for worker's severe injuries No. 3 Mount Zion football stumbles late, falls to No. 2 Rochester Blue Mound teen known as 'grave singer' proves it's not too late for one more show Forsyth cannabis store set to open Saturday Vote for this week’s Herald & Review Player of the Week Decatur council approves enterprise zone expansion in Mount Zion for proposed surgical facility Military veterans take flight from Decatur Airport 9 takeaways from Week 2 of high school football: MacArthur 2-0 for first time since 2018 “So as a little kid, I always thought that was a very special location,” he said. That appreciation grew as he got older and began enjoying the magnificent view of the nearby lake while dining with friends on the restaurant’s deck. Parker said he began pondering some 10 years ago things that could be done to enhance the venue and make the experience even better for its customers. Those thoughts gave way to serious discussions with Todd Mason and Wilson some three years ago, which came to a head in the past few months. After efforts to hire the perfect general manager to lead their venture came up short, it was decided that Wilson, who has extensive experience operating local restaurants and bars, would assume that responsibility to get the project moving. Wilson said there was something about this project that drew him in, making him want to be a part of it and see it move beyond the discussion stage. "When you stand behind that bar and you look out and you see the lake, man, there's just something special about it," he said. That decision cleared the way for the ownership change and renovations. “As proud owners of the Beach House, we’ve had the immense pleasure of welcoming so many wonderful guests into our little slice of paradise. Over the years, your laughter, stories, and cherished moments have filled this place with warmth and life,” read a post on the restaurant’s Facebook page from Todd and Angie Mason. Going against the advice of some trusted friends, Todd Mason emerged from the gas station business and purchased Marcia's Waterfront on Aug. 1, 2005. He selected the name Beach House to tap into the building's beginning as the bathhouse for visitors of the Lake Decatur Beach. In this 1957 file photo, swimmers enjoy a break from the heat by taking a swim at the Decatur Municipal Beach. In the background is the bathhouse, which is now home to the Beach House. Scott Perry “Now, as we turn the page to a new chapter, we want to say thank you — to our guests, to our employees, and to everyone who has made this journey so special. The memories we’ve shared will stay with us forever,” the post read. “We are super excited for the new owners. Their vision for the future is absolutely amazing and long overdue for this beautiful historic site. In good hands, the Beach House will remain a place of joy and inspiration for many years to come.” Contacted later, Mason reiterated his confidence in Parker and Wilson. “When I sat down with the new owners in the very beginning, I explained that I wasn’t really an owner. The business and building were bigger and more important than me. I was simply trying to be a good steward for the community. That being said, they both smiled in agreement and I knew that this was going to be a good decision,” Mason said. “I'm looking forward to what they do because, I tell you what, the plans that they have are amazing and I think Decatur is really going to be proud of what they see when they walk into the Beach House the next time. I'm super excited for these guys,” said Mason, who plans to be their biggest cheerleader. Far removed from his poor upbringing, Parker is a certified financial adviser with Northwestern Mutual and co-founder of Parker Mathis Wealth Advisors. Parker said his financial security provides him the opportunity make a significant investment toward the improvements with the goal of just breaking even and the prospect for much, much more. “Where else anywhere within a two-hour radius do you have a more gorgeous place to eat,” he said. Parker hopes to build on the restaurant’s past success by infusing culinary concepts he has encountered while dining out during his extensive travels. “I’m trying to build my favorite place to eat on the planet,” he said. While there will be items that remain on the menu at all times, plans call for quarterly menu changes. “It gives you a reason to go (to the restaurant) quarterly just because you know it’s going to be something different all the time,” Parker said. The bathhouse as it appeared in the 1960. Originally designed as an open-air pavilion on the upper level with a bathhouse below, it was built in the 1920s to serve the Decatur Municipal Beach. In the 1980s, the structure was transformed into a restaurant, with several successful owners taking charge over the years. Scott Perry Wilson said the plan is to create a revolving menu that includes a variety of unique items, especially when it comes to seafood, made from the "best of the best" ingredients. The goal of the renovations is to create a vibe that engages the customers, making them want to put down their phones. “When people step into the restaurant we want them to engage each other and the environment,” Parker said. Parker said the dining room renovation is phase one of the improvements. Phase two will bring improvements this summer to the outdoor dining area. As for the existing banquet area, the future of that space is undecided. Parker tossed out the prospect of it becoming a sports bar, but added they will be looking to their customers for more direction. For Wilson, who has been part of many bar/restaurant openings, the same thing that makes it fun also makes it challenging. "The most fun is just every day, when you come in here and see all the dramatic changes," he said. But he said the quick turnaround — construction started Jan. 6 — is also a source of stress. "We've completely remodeled this whole thing, so it's been pretty intense," he said" Parker praised the relationship they have built with the park district, which owns the historic structure, and the support it has shown as he turns his dream into reality. “The team meets weekly and it’s clear that a lot of thought and care is being put into these changes, and the end result promises to elevate the overall experience for everyone who visits,” said Clay Gerhard, the park district’s executive director. Gerhard also took time to praise the Masons. “Many restaurants don’t survive beyond five or 10 years so for the Masons to have owned and operated the Beach House successfully for over 20 years, I think that is a testament to their work ethic and dedication,” Gerhard said. “It would be interesting to know how many community events, private events, weddings, and other memories have been made in the Beach House over the years and to think of what new memories are going to be created once the new Beach House opens for business.” As it has in the past, Parker and Gerhard are hopeful the Beach House will once again be the catalyst for even more improvements along the lakefront that will appeal to visitors and enhance efforts to recruit workers and businesses to the community. In recent years the area has seen the addition of the amphitheater, Splash Cove waterpark, Overlook Adventure Park and new boat docks. Also included in the park district’s master plan is Chandler Cove, an area proposed for condominium-style residential developments, and the shopping and restaurants in the area around the Beach House. “This revitalization, along with the development that’s taken place in Nelson Park over the past decade, continues to solidify Nelson Park as the premier entertainment district in our community. We’re optimistic that additional restaurants and dining options will be added along the lakefront in the future, as we work to continue enhancements to our overall quality of life here in Decatur,” Gerhard said. History photos: Fun on Lake Decatur No sweat? 1984: Searching for ways to cool off is one of the "hottest" activities these days in Central Illinois as summer wears on. Shelly Riggs (left), Gary Edwards and Richard Edwards, all of Decatur, find a boat dock on Lake Decatur the perfect place to soak up some sunshine and cool off in the water at the same time. H&R file photo Catchings some Zs 1989: If nothing else, Rick Comer caught some Zs. The Terre Haute, Ind., man was fishing off a dock on Lake Decatur Thursday when the warm sun lulled him into a nap. Comer was visiting the Michelle Stark family of Decatur. The strong sun - a welcome sight- made the 68-degree high temperature seem warmer. H&R file photo To each his own 1988: Taking full advantage of Tuesday's record-breaking July-in-April temperatures on lake Decatur were sailboater Dave Lee and fisherman Dan Taylor, who is from Fairview Heights. Tuesday's high temperature reached 85 degrees, breaking the old mark of 84, which was set in 1929. H&R file photo Temporary dam 1989: These fishermen try their luck Thursday near the opening cut in the temporary dam at Rea's Bridge H&R file photo Floating water bed 1989: It was a relaxing way to start the Fourth of July weekend for Randy Allen, who gave the appearance of having a floating water bed Friday near the boat docks on Lake Decatur. Allen was enjoying the day's near-perfect 88-degree high temperature. H&R file photo Taking it easy 1970: A bright, sunny day is for taking it easy, and that's what this couple is doing, unmindful of the boats sailing on Lake Decatur. H&R file photo Sailors' delight 1981: "Red sky at night, sailors delight; red sky in the morning, sailors take warning." The sky over Decatur was unusually red during Wednesday's sunset, which augured well for these sailors on Lake Decatur. H&R file photo Sh-h-h-h, quiet please 1990: Ron White relaxes on an air mattress near a buoy on Lake Decatur Sunday after playing a round of golf with two of his friends. White, who has a boat docked at the marina, was waiting to go out water skiing with his buddies. H&R file photo Beautiful balmy evening 1992: Sam Blair, 16, enjoyed a beautiful balmy evening and sunset in Decatur Friday as he fished off a bridge on Lost Bridge Road. Decatur recorded a high of 85 Friday, while Hillsboro recorded 88 - the high for Central Illinois. More of the same is expected throughout Labor Day weekend with showers possible Sunday and Monday. H&R file photo Warm stroll on cold water 1981: Teen-agers (from left) Loronzo Davis, Mike Landers and Bill Bryles walked on the ice on Lake Decatur Saturday, drawing the notice of the ducks, who wasted no time heading skyward. The three also drew the attention of the photographer because of their spring attire. H&R file photo Wind surfing 1987: Tom sly, 67, found a way to beat the heat Wednesday as he pulls up his wind surfing board and sails. H&R file photo The water's fine 1988: The sun's warm and the water's sparkling. Join a group of Central Illinoisans as they enjoy one of the city's finest resources - Lake Decatur. H&R file photo Tourist attraction 1985: Central Illinois lakes such as Lake Decatur are attractions for tourists. H&R file photo Crappie report 1990: Brothers Mike and Jim Kresse of Decatur cast their lines Wednesday along the Lake Decatur docks, in search of crappie. The warmer weather will bring more company for fishermen such as the Kresses. H&R file photo Hanging in there 1991: While the wind filling their sails wasn't as brisk as they had hoped, Decatur residents Patty Cutright and Dave Berndt spent part of Monday afternoon wind surfing on Lake Decatur. Cutright, a physical education instructor, just recently took up the sport, but Berndt has been pursuing windsurfing for more than five years. H&R file photo Holiday sailing The Yankee Lady, a 19-foot sailboat belonging to former Decatur resident Jack Bankson, took a turn about Lake Decatur Sunday afternoon. Bankson, in front above, now lives in Mebane N.C.., but returned to visit relatives on a Christmas cruise. Behind Bankson is his son-in-law, Mike Jackson; also on board were Charles Hughes, another son-in-law, and Rick Taylor. the Yankee Lady is to sail today, also. H&R file photo Mapping bottoms 1931 H&R file photo Lost Bridge 1992: Nice weather Sunday stimulated plenty of lake activity as people boated, water skied, picnicked and fished. Nick Imel, 8, tried his luck by dropping his line under Lost Bridge with his father Steve. H&R file photo "Decatur Belle" 1966: The "Decatur Belle" an excursion boat now making runs on Lake Decatur, took its first passengers aboard Friday. The passengers were a group of 80 Latham grade school pupils. The boat will make hourly cruises beginning at noon each day except Sunday, when rides will begin at 10 a.m. The trips will cover the two basins of the lake on each side of Lost Bridge. H&R file photo "Sport Speedster" 1948: D. R. Hill of Decatur demonstrates a  new Higgins "Sport Speedster" of which he is the Decatur distributor. With a top cruising speed of 44 miles an hour, Mr. Hill believes his speedster is the fastest boat on Lake Decatur H&R file photo Sand Creek Bridge 1950: When it gets too hot for comfort, according to these boys, the best relief is to dive off Sand Creek bridge, across Lake Decatur, near Danceland. These youths would be hotter, however, if they were caught in this escapade. Swimming in Lake Decatur is permitted only where lifeguards are on duty. H&R file photo Seaplane 1948: This seaplane has been put on Lake Decatur by Clarence Bowman, Spangler Heights. A Cub, with floats attached, has been based at a dock on the lake near the home of Mr. Bowman. The plane will be flown under a charter as a non-profit flying club. The plane was based previously at St. Louis. H&R file photo Shimmering waters 1989: What a difference a year makes! Dale Zimmer of Decatur plies through the simmering waters of Lake Decatur. H&R file photo Evening canoe ride 1963: Jim Downey and Bob Musson, staff members at Camp Robert Faries, enjoy an evening canoe ride on Lake Decatur. The Boy Scouts are offered swimming, canoeing, rowing, lifesaving, archery, mo-skeet and have a handicrafts program at the camp. Mo-skeet is a form of trap shooting with b-b's or small shot. The boys cook one meal outdoors each day with the other two served in the dining hall. The camp also has complete badge programs and instruction in caring for axes and knives. H&R file photo The Scratcher 1963: W.G. Traver and grandson Andy Zeaman ride in the "Scratcher" H&R file photo Skipping stones 1993: Chris Carnahan, Richard Myers and Joshua Butts stopped their bike ride long enough to skip a few rocks on Lake Decatur in Nelson Park Friday afternoon. In addition to Easter, the boys are looking forward to a four-day weekend that's predicted to be in the upper 60s, but with a chance of showers each day. Many Central Illinois residents took advantage of the day off from work or school Friday to go to the parks or to attend special Good Friday services where they worship.
